reviews.review: If you liked the the 1st one, you will not be disappointed by the 2nd one. Hopefully it will lead into a 3rd.

If there was 1 thing that the 1st movie didn't had was more moments between ben and jon. Who would have knew they make a pair a good brother's if they were given enough screen time. A mixture of action, comedy, despair. Lots of comedic moments between the 2. Wroth a watch

Loved this movie, its even better than the first.

Shifting its focus more squarely onto Ben Affleck and Jon Bernthal, The Accountant 2 changes the tone and style of the original ‚Äî trading in its distinct suspense angle for more commercially popular elements. While the sequel ups the entertainment factor, it loses a bit of the original‚Äôs unique flavor in the process.

Good movie but not as good as the original. Some really good moments and scenes and ALL actors did an excellent job in their roles. Some technology in use seems a little unbelievable and Marybeth Medinas origins from the first flick would probably disqualify her from the position she holds in this film. But, all-in-all my wife and I enjoyed the movie.
Great sequel but not at all like the first version.

Nailed it! I loved the first one, but this sequel actually tops it. Everything: acting, directing, story, script, cinematography...was absolutely on point. Ben Affleck and Jon Bernthal are incredible together and funny as hell. With so many forgettable movies out there lately, this one is a standout. Trust me: The Accountant 2 is not to be missed!

But this movie is not it.

Finally watched the original on demand a week or two ago. Glad I got to see this one on the big screen. It seemed to have a better story and less violence, even though I am happy to say I was not the only one in the theatre laughing at some of the bits of violence. :)

CONTAINS SPOILERS: I love the first one. I couldn't wait for the second. I went to see it twice before writing this. Its not good. They omit a lot of the action that was in the first...maybe they wanted to save money on choreography or something but there were minimal fight scenes. The culmination of the bad guy and chick assassin that we waited for the whole movie to see...showed her follow him out of a door with a knife...that was it. Lame. Too much touchy-feely crap in this one that wasn't needed. There's an entire scene in the beginning where Chris is at a speed dating thing that made zero sense and was completely disjointed from the rest of the movie. The plot is confusing and hard to follow. Its better the second time because you already understand where they're going, but its difficult to follow the first time. Ultimately, this didn't compare with the first one. They made it more of a drama with precious few action scenes.

This movie was good. I was not sitting in the theater wondering when the movie would be over. It had some funny parts in it and some good action scenes. A nice continuation from the first movie. I did not leave the theater disappointed.
I just enjoyed the film. The brothers were fabulous together and some of the scenes quite funny. The violence is definitely there but then you know that if you saw Accountant 1.

This movie is one of the best thriller action films of 2025, it always finds new ways to level up the stakes and plot twists to surprise your mind in ways you didn‚Äôt know was coming. It also shows the emotional brotherly connection Christian and Braxton have and how they reconcile. But I still can suggest some changes to the film: 1. There was no resolution between Wolff and Maybeth. If I were the director, I would have the characters have one last talk about justice and vigilantism.  2. Ana√Øs needs some more screen time and plot development. For example, she doesn‚Äôt even try to meet her son one last time. If I were Gavin O‚Äô Connor, I would put this one last confrontation into the script so that the movie would be emotional. I would also have the assassin thank the brotherly duo for saving her son, and add how she kills Burke with an epic yet tense moment.  3. I would add an post-credits scene of Christian meeting the girl she met in the bar, and create an awkward yet hilarious date night with his brother secretly watching, while laughing. I would rate this a 7.2/10.
Can‚Äôt compare with the first movie. Very predictable.
Action packed and witty!
Started out interesting, but got typical cheesy repetitive Bollywood low budget, action. Waste of 11. Wait for the stream release and pay 4 for the 48 hr rental and you have 2 hrs to waste.

Watched for the first time, last week. Reviewing, but will likely edit after a few watches... It's good. Same solid performances and action, with the same feel as the first film. However, there seems to be more character bonding and connection in this instalment. Not a bad thing, per se, but the story is slower as a result, and didn't deliver that 'punch' in the same way the first film did on my initial viewing

The first movie was a pretty interesting concept and story looking at someone who not only learned to live with a challenge, but harnessed it into becoming a general badass. The Accountant 2 turned Ben Affleck's character into a Jason Bourne type person, who has the support of an army of neruodivergent children, hacking into surveillance systems and computers at a moments notice. The first movie Affleck was an actual accountant, in The Accountant 2 I think Affleck did his neurodivergent number thing once and that was while roughly interrogating someone on the fly. Outside of that he was just doing spy type stuff. It was just kind of another generic shoot-em-up movie cashing in on the name of a film that actually had an interesting concept. Affleck seemed more twitchy than autistic, but my favorite part might have been the Deputy Director of a Federal Agency freaking out while some children hack into the photos of a private citizen. Like it's 2025 and she's well up in the Federal Government, Snowden released the info on Federal surveillance of US citizens like 15 years ago. Grow up.

Liked the movie. Nice segway from first accountant to next one..The main action scene was very unbelieveable...like an old jackie chan movie...so many guys with guns coming out from everywhere...taking care of a prison for kids...really?

While I admit the lighter tone might not be to everyone's tastes, especially if they preferred the more consistently gritty tone of the original film, I ultimately thought that The Accountant 2 was a really good sequel. Good performances, well-directed moments of suspense and brutal action, amusing comedy whilst still knowing when to read the room and, now that the (admittedly obvious) twist from the first film is no longer an issue, enjoyable buddy comedy chemistry between Ben Affleck and Jon Bernthal. If I had a nickel for every time The Punisher was involved with both the film and TV Daredevils within the same calendar year, I'd have two nickels, which isn't a lot but it's weird that it happened twice. Not to mention a surprisingly heartwarming ending. Overall, a worthy sequel despite the likelihood of this film meeting the same fate as Furiosa of being a box-office bomb as a result of a nine-year gap between movies that caused any hype for a follow-up to fizzle out by the time it finally came out. Not that this has stopped the filmmakers for figuring out ideas for a third film.

The Accountant 2 is nowhere near as good as the first movie. A great cast keeps this from being a bad movie for sure. We don't get to see a physical encounter between Justine and Ben's character, which would have been ideal. A little ridiculousness occurs with the kids helping Justine like they are all computer savants and Ray King's death scene was a little wonky also. Braxton was the most entertaining character this time around, Anais would come in second - she was a great addition and will hopefully appear in the 3rd movie with the return of Anna Kendrick.

Well, what can I say!? When I saw the trailer I was afraid it would be a brutal war like shootout throughout the movie, but fortunately it wasn't. What it wasn't either was to be on par with the first edition. While pretty much nothing was predictable in the first movie, which made it captivating and cool, here in the second edition pretty much every development was clear from early on or coming up throughout to even the dumbest of movie goer. There were no surprises, except the fact that the boring, idiotic, childish chit-chat of two professional assassins throughout various endless scenes was uncalled for and completely ludicrous. And one key factor of the story, the kids of victims forced into prostitution and slavery, not being instantly clear to an accountant and assassin working for drug lords, is just plain stupid. The movie has its silly moments, which lighten up the flick. And while the action scenes are there, quite spread out throughout the 2 hours, all seem to be rather of B-movie quality. All in all it's watchable, but a very far cry from the original one. 5/10 points!

Cynthia Addai-Robinson‚Äòs character is also painfully bland and unremarkable. Some good action scenes & humor. Some pointless violence for drama‚Äôs sake. A lot of headshots. Die Fortsetzung steht dem Vorg√§nger in nichts nach. Die Geschichte hat einen sehr guten roten Faden, nach dem sich alles richtet. Auch das "Upgrade" mit seinem Bruder und somit auch logische Weiterentwicklung der Geschichte, macht Spass. Die Beiden liefern sich Streitereien, die entwaffnend lustig sind. Die Macken des Bruders sind Gleichwertig. Nun zu den intensiven Actionszenen, wie, teilweise aus Kriegsszenarios. Dies ist alles andere als B Action. Die Gefechte sind sehr gut Choreographiert. Es ist √ºberraschend, nach teilweise m√§√üigen Kritiken. Hier wurde sich au√üerordentliche M√ºhe gegeben, das: Wenige gegen Viele Szenario, so √ºberzeugend wie m√∂glich zu gestalten. Das funktioniert. Ist sogar √ºberzeugender, als John Wick. Absolute Empfehlung

Loved the movie! The dynamic between the brothers created several instances of brother rivalry throughout, and the comedic innuendo was great - you‚Äôll laugh throughout. Action was great as well - top notch. There is reference about a family from Ecuador and the final scene takes place in Central America, so MAGA will blame Hollywood for evoking the ‚Äúimmigration debate‚Äù even though there is no reference to Geopolitics at all, as it‚Äôs not engrained in the plot. The plot is layered and complex and I will see it again when it comes out on TV - play close attention to the plot from the beginning or you may get lost at times. Another reason why folks may have liked the second less - this movie isn‚Äôt for stupid people‚Ä¶lol. The first movie was the ‚Äústage-setter‚Äù that provided context and this is a continuation - so I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs fair to compare the two. Again - loved this movie. ü§ô

In this sequel to the 2016 action thriller "The Accountant," the opening scene, thanks in large part to the performance of the great J.K. Simmons, is intriguing; unfortunately, it is all downhill from there. A dubious plot where no less than - get this! - a deputy director of FinCEN (Financial Crimes Enforcement Network) played by Cynthia Addai-Robinson appears to blow off all of her high-level responsibilities to personally pursue a case that normally would be relegated to the inbox of the LAPD, and in doing so brings in Christian Wolff (Ben Afleck), AKA "The Accountant!" This autistically compulsive genius, who's not afraid to break some bones, in turn recruits his shady brother, Braxton (Jon Bernthal) who genuinely enjoys inflicting physical pain, including shooting people. And while Braxton and brother Christian have a strained relationship, Braxton doesn't think twice about dropping everything at a moments notice and bolting Berlin to join his pain-in-the-ass autistic brother on the west coast. Unfortunately, the movie morphs into a bad crime-action version of "Rain Man." Chrsitian & Braxton struggle to reconnect as they pursue the bad guys - a human trafficking mob and a shadowy female assassin; but no chemistry ever develops between the characters. Attempts at humor come off as lame. One of the biggest problems is Afleck is terribly miscast as the autistic Christian: he isn't interesting; just boring and bland. But I guess that can be said of most accountants (just kidding! :D )

It's an Affleck & Berthal Classic. This pretty much fixes all the fundamental problems the first one had. Jumpy editing, very scattered weak script, wooden acting, and a very sloppy/shaky first half. All of that is gone here. Replaced with a focused script that is significantly stronger, better execution across the board and good chemistry between the two leads. It's like a quasi buddy cop mixed with a serious crime thriller. This has almost nothing to do with accounting or the crporate world at all. It's such a stark change of subject matter with the only recurring theme of mental health & autism. The pacing is really good here and everything else is solid. It does have problems with it can feel like two seperate films sometimes. The character development is well done and the moments of the two leads together are the strongest and best scenes but in the end it doesn't tie consistently with the crime/child rescue/drug cartel/Hitwoman plot. The Hitwoman is really cool and such an awesome idea. I wish it would've focused more on her sometimes. Such a cool character. The fights in this are just as good if not slightly better than the first also. This also is very much a crowd pleaser as well. So it wears multiple hats and can have trouble with tying it all together which gives it a slightly bloated feel. But the direction is pretty good here and the fact everything is much more consistent here helps so much and one can easily look past the flaws with this. Anyone who is a fan of the first, the director, any actors in this, or action/crime thrillers should check this out.
That was one of the most entertaining movies I have seen in a long time. Ben Affleck is a major talent. Jon Bernthal played a tremendous role across from Affleck. Action packed!
